Award.AwardTitle: Elucidating the Mechanics of Tsunami Generating Earthquake Rupture with Long Period Seismology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Submarine earthquakes are capable of generating uncharacteristically large tsunamis, and drastically increase the hazard facing most of the world's population, which currently lives along the coastlines. Current techniques used to study submarine earthquakes are expensive and cannot be applied to most earthquakes of interest. The lack of observations has hindered the understanding of whether an earthquake will displace the seafloor and increase the likelihood of generating a significant tsunami. The theory developed in this project will provide a new fundamental tool for the study of submarine earthquakes with significant scientific and societal implications. A new framework will be developed that overcomes previous theoretical limitations and allows us to develop an easily utilized, inexpensive tool which will allow for the detection of slip on the seafloor from distant recordings of ground motion alone. This tool will then be used to examine giant earthquakes in the last 15 years that produced devastating tsunamis, as well as recent moderate-size earthquakes from around the world. By studying a large number of earthquakes with the newly developed tool, a better understanding will be obtained of why some earthquakes displace the seafloor while others do not. This project could provide an improvement for tsunami hazard assessment. The project supports the training of a postdoctoral investigator.

The first component of this project will establish the theoretical and observational framework required to distinguish events for which slip reached and did not reach the surface. This theory will provide a simple seismological diagnostic tool, and has the added benefit of complementing numerical models, seafloor instrumentation, drilling, or marine surveys. The second component of this project will provide the necessary observations required to determine the physical mechanisms controlling submarine surface rupture by applying the diagnostic to long-period seismic data from a large number of events recorded by the Global Seismographic Network. The new framework will be validated using the large amount of shallow slip that was measured to have occurred during the 2011 Tohoku-Oki Earthquake. To what extent this type of shallow slip is observed in giant megathrust earthquakes, such as the 2010 and 2015 Chile and the 2004 and 2010 Sumatra tsunami earthquakes, as well as recent moderate-size earthquakes will be determined. Using the outcome of the survey of large and moderate-size earthquakes, an attempt will be made to determine the properties of fault zones (e.g., presence of accretionary wedge, subducted sediment thickness, fault dip-angle, etc.) that govern the rupture of the shallowest part of plate boundary.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The participants of this study, the postdoc fellow and PI from the Harvard Seismology Group, have worked to advance the mathematical theory underpinning Elucidating the Mechanics of Tsunami Generating Earthquake Rupture with Long Period Seismology. The theoretical advances made in this study will serve to advance our understanding of shallow-earthquake rupture, and consequently the generation of tsunami hazards. The framework newly developed in this study seeks to capture the permanent discontinuous displacement of the seafloor, which is chiefly responsible for the exaggerated vertical motions which generate large tsunamis. This theory allows for the development of a simple diagnostic tool which can be applied to real data.

Due to the advent of modern continuous seismological and geodetic networks, and the recordings of numerous recent moderate to large earthquakes our understanding of the megathrust fault zone has evolved to include a spectrum of faulting behaviors, however, techniques used to determine whether slip reached the seafloor in submarine earthquakes are expensive and cannot be applied to most earthquakes of interest. Consequently, current methods do not allow us to readily study the dynamics of these near-surface ruptures. This lack of observations has hindered the understanding of the physical conditions controlling whether an earthquake will displace the seafloor and increase the likelihood of generating a significant tsunami. The theoretical results of this project provide an opportunity to significantly advance the knowledge of the spatial and temporal release of stored shallow strain-energy near the trench during earthquake rupture. Seismic fault slip extending to the trench drastically changes the seismic hazard facing most the world’s population, which currently lives along the coastlines. The theory and diagnostic tool developed in this proposal will provide a new fundamental seismological tool for the study of submarine earthquakes with significant multidisciplinary and societal implications.

The participants of this study worked to establish the theoretical and observational frameworks required to distinguish events for which slip reached and did not reach the surface. The theory developed in this study seeks to mathematically define an equivalent set of tractions that represent the creation of a new surface. This new surface is generated when slip extends to the free surface. In the canonical derivation, the surface of the Earth is not deformed. In this theory the boundary is moving, and deforming. In order to take advantage of the machinery previously developed which utilizes reciprocal theorems, the theory developed in this study represents the discontinuous deformation of the seafloor using an equivalent set of surface tractions. For the case of a simple rectangular fault which intersects the free surface, the canonical theory requires that the slip on the edge of the fault go to zero, and thus the so called “stress-glut” vanishes. However, in this study the slip extends all the way to the surface, creating a discontinuity in the displacement field which is described by a line dislocation. In this framework we calculate the equilibrium displacement of the surface which would result from this line dislocation, and then solve for an equivalent set of surface tractions which would produce an equivalent elastic response in the Earth. These surface tractions can then be used in a derived expression for the excitation coefficients to calculate displacement seismograms using normal-mode summation.
